In the previous posts, we have assumed that only one kernel is launched at a time. But this is not all that kernels can do. They can be launched sequentially or in parallel. Itâ€™s just that if multiple kernels are launched in parallel, CUDA streams must be used.

What is a Stream?

In CUDA, stream refers to a single operation sequence on a GPU device. Every CUDA kernel is invoked on an independent stream; not always true for other architectures, but true for K20 architecture. If only one kernel is invoked, the default stream, stream0, is used. If n kernels are invoked in parallel, n streams need to be used.
